page.title: 01LITTLEPORT, CAMBRIDGESHIRE
page.content: Littleport is a village of 6000 people, sited at the north end of a 30 metre high hill, sticking up out of the flat fen country. In the{Domesday {Book}31 men lived there. The settlement would have been dry above the fen, which flooded in the winter, and next to the River Ouse, which provided trade and eels. The hill soil is clay, but it is surrounded by rich fen peat, reclaimed in the C17, when the area was drained by{Cornelius {Vermuyden.}Local people objected to the improvements and later, in 1816, 5 were hanged during the {Littleport {Bread Riots.} Fishing and wildfowling now only occur as sport. Arable farming is still the important source of income, while river transport has been superceded by road transport, there being several lorry firms.
